title: How stress can show up as physical pain
content: In the weeks leading up to the move, Peter was experiencing some physical pain in his body. Amazingly, the pain dissipated once the move was complete. Mechanistically, it’s hard to explain “why higher levels of cortisol. . .would actually lead to physical pain in my body. But there’s no question about it.”

title: Tips for adjusting to a new time zone
content: Prior to making the move, Peter’s family slowly adjusted their bedtime and wake schedule over the course of 10 days. By the time they made the move, their internal clocks had already adjusted. Jet lag protocol Example: Say you are going to London where it’s 5 hours ahead. On the day of departure, the idea would be to wake up super early to match London time (e.g., 3am). That will allow you to be sleepy at a normal time once in London.

title: Literature overview of heat and cold therapy
content: Peter’s research team has put extensive effort into understanding the current literature on heat and cold therapy. The idea was to see if there was any reliable evidence that showed either heat or cold therapy to impact lifespan or healthspan. Often, heat and cold therapy studies are lumped together when they are really separate topics. An example of “lumping” is clearly seen in a large editorial paper that claimed heat and cold could positively impact in several ways: 1-A wide range of physiological responses including: resistance to cardiovascular disease and mortality, endothelial function and arterial stiffness, walking ability and lower limb perfusion; shear pattern, blood pressure and circulating endothelin‐1 concentrations, glucose metabolism, autonomic nervous activity, cerebral protection, stress resistance.

title: Cold therapy for delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS)
content: Peter’s team found that there was evidence that ice baths could help reduce DOMS. The greatest benefits to reducing DOMS occurred when treated 24 to 72 hours post exercise. Treatment should not be administered in the first hour post exercise.

title: Reducing DOMS related to strength training
content: The greatest benefits to reducing DOMS occurred when treated 24 to 72 hours post exercise. However, when strength training, there is an inflammatory response post-exercise that is beneficial. And since the cold therapy could reduce inflammation, you have to think about that tradeoff. Some recommendations found in the literature say you should not administer cold therapy in the first hour post-exercise.

title: Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for improving performance exercise
content: Acetaminophen, on the other hand, actually improves performance (especially endurance exercise). The mechanism of action is not clear—but there are 2 plausible explanations: 1-The reduction in temperature. 2-The reduction of pain.

title: The upshot on cold therapy for DOMS
content: It reduces delayed onset muscle soreness, but the timing of when you administer cold matters. The closer you administer cold therapy to the bout of exercise, the more you may actually blunt the benefits of exercise.

title: Quality of evidence for cold therapy for depression or immune enhancement
content: For depression: Pretty clear that we don’t really know if there’s a benefit based on the 2008 study. Cold therapy for immune enhancement: Some studies have shown that cryotherapy decreases inflammation. Although, not all results agree. Even if it does lower inflammation… we get back to the issue of whether that process is blunting the beneficial inflammation post-exercise. If cryotherapy is addressing chronic inflammation, that’s one thing, but from the acute perspective, that inflammation might be doing something that’s ultimately beneficial.

title: Brown Adipose Tissue (BAT)
content: Brown adipose tissue (BAT) is a type of fat that is more metabolically active and therefore it becomes another energy consumer suggesting that having more BAT may increase the calories you’re burning. There may be other health benefits of BAT due to “batokines”—bioactive peptides and proteins secreted by BAT. The literature generally explores two things: 1—Whether increasing BAT increases energy expenditure—which therefore could help with obesity, insulin sensitivity, metabolic health, etc. 2—The impact of “batokines”—bioactive peptides and proteins secreted by BAT. Possible benefits of batokines: Heart—cardioprotection via FGF21 and IL-6, Pancreas—preservation of beta cells, Liver—fatty acid oxidation, so presumably it might lower fatty liver, lower white adipose tissue, so you have more lipolysis and more glucose uptake, Inhibition of myostatin—potentially the increase in brown adipose tissue activity inhibits myostatin.

title: Cold Therapy and Brown Adipose Tissue (BAT)
content: Cold exposure activates brown adipose tissue. Having more brown adipose tissue appears to play a positive role in health in the ways mentioned above. BAT volume actually changes more so with an improvement in metabolic health via exercise. Cold exposure does seem to activate the BAT, but it’s unclear whether or not that actually makes a difference.

title: Cold Exposure vs Exercise
content: Cold exposure activates heat shock proteins as does exercise. Would simply doing more exercise—in place of the time you would otherwise dedicate towards cold exposure—have the same net benefit?

title: Opportunity Cost
content: What gets overlooked in these discussions is opportunity cost. After answering the safety question, you look at benefits—and as we’re seeing with cold therapy, it’s pretty hard to find real, tangible benefits to cold therapy when you hold the therapy up to the same sort of standard that we hold other therapies like exercise or heat therapy. What about the fact that you just spent an hour doing effectively nothing when that hour could have been spent doing something with a known benefit?

title: Harm in Cold Therapy
content: Cold therapy is a broad term that includes cryotherapy, plunging (ice bath), and cold exposure (mild, prolonged cold exposure). Not too much risk in cryotherapy (some blisters and pain during treatment) and mild cold exposure. Cold water immersion has the most risk associated with it, mostly due to afterdrop. Afterdrop occurs when your core temperature drops from something safe, like 96-97, to 92-93, which could result in a ventricular arrhythmia.

title: Heat Therapy Benefits
content: Peter and Bob are more optimistic on heat therapy versus cold therapy as a potential tool to enhance longevity. Sauna before bed is one of the best tools to sleep especially if you follow it with an immediate cold dunk just or got into a cold bed. Other purported clinical benefits of heat therapy include decreased pain, decreased risk of cardiovascular disease, improved endurance and performance, and decreased risk of dementia and Alzheimer’s Disease.

title: Improved Insulin sensitivity and glucose control
content: Heat therapy may reduce fasting glucose, body weight, and adiposity.

title: Decreased risk of respiratory disease
content: Heat therapy can also improve the symptoms of asthma, bronchitis, and pneumonia.

title: Physiological effects of heat therapy
content: The physiological effects of heat therapy include increased GH levels, increased prolactin in both sexes, increased cortisol immediately after heat therapy, and a likely increase in other biomarkers.

title: Longevity benefits of sauna
content: A study out of Finland comparing different frequencies of sauna use found that those who used the sauna at least four times a week for at least 20 minutes at a temperature of at least 172 to 174 Fahrenheit had a 40% lower relative risk of all-cause mortality and an 18% lower absolute risk.

title: Nutrition-related findings
content: Important to note that these are NOT really high risk people, increasing the impressiveness of the numbers. Stroke reduction: 8% absolute risk reduction. Alzheimer’s disease reduction: 3% absolute risk reduction.

title: Limitations in the sauna literature
content: In this cohort of sauna users, you’re dealing with a highly privileged group of individuals. Can afford your own sauna. Have access to leisure. Have resources to buy healthier, more expensive food. This is considered a healthy user bias—one of the biggest challenges that epidemiologists face when they try to make associations into causations.

title: Heart rate increase could possibly just be a marker, not a “maker”, of health
content: Heart rate may increase up to a hundred beats a minute during moderate sauna bathing sessions and up to 150 beats per minute during more intense, warm sauna bathing. That sounds very similar to what happens when a 50-year-old engages in endurance exercise.

title: Possible mechanisms conferring the longevity benefits of sauna, and how it compares to exercise
content: Overall, the data is robust in support of heat therapy.

title: Sauna and Hormones
content:
There are increased growth hormone levels
Increased prolactin
Increased cortisol, 
And other hormones likely increase: norepinephrine, renin activity, white blood cell count, and heat shock proteins

title: Bob's Personal Sauna Regimen
content:
Five times per week
60 minute sessions
He personally really enjoys it
He feels mentally and intellectually stimulated (almost like a “runner’s high”) — He brings papers and articles inside the sauna

title: Opportunity Cost of Sauna
content:
Bob personally does not feel there to be an opportunity cost
In fact, he finds it a tad challenging to engage in a similar amount time in zone 2 exercise (which presumably is the closest type of exercise to dry sauna)
As a bonus, he can be more “productive” in the sauna (e.g., reading papers) as compared to during exercise

title: Peter's Final Takeaways on Sauna
content:
Prior to this big analysis done by Peter and his team, Peter never really viewed sauna as having any longevity benefit
But now, Peter is ready to add sauna into his tool kit for longevity
That said, exercise is probably giving you many of the same benefits
In fact, Peter would place exercise above sauna as exercise comes with a number of benefits that sauna doesn’t including (but not limited to) stability and structural benefits and some of the mitochondrial fuel partitioning benefits
